Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Interventional Microscopy for In-vivo Investigations of Brain Function

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0954796
Hillman

The proposed program will develop and refine a platform for in-vivo "Interventional Microscopy". The vision is to create an in-vivo microscope that can not just observe living cells in their natural environment, but directly interact with them. To achieve this they will implement photo-manipulation techniques more commonly applied to in-vitro studies, and translate them for use in-vivo in small animals. By refining experimental paradigms and demonstrating the efficacy of Interventional Microscopy techniques, they will introduce these potentially transformative new tools to a broad audience of biomedical researchers. To achieve these goals, they will start by developing a combined two-photon microscopy and photomanipulation instrument, based around an existing home-built in-vivo two-photon system. The design incorporates two independently focused and shaped beams from two different pulsed lasers, and will be operated by custom-written software. They will then begin developing and optimizing in-vivo techniques for using photoactivable compounds, as well as exploring optical trapping and particle-manipulation techniques in-vivo. To achieve, this they will develop and optimize procedures for in-vivo loading of photomanipulatable
substances, as well as developing calibration techniques and controls to ensure that lightactivation in-vivo is reliable and well controlled. They plan to apply these techniques to their ongoing in-vivo studies of neurovascular coupling; the interrelation between blood flow and neuronal activity in the brain. Interventional Microscopy techniques will allow them to selectively manipulate the cells and vessels of the living brain, allowing in depth characterization of fundamental chemical and cellular mechanisms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to develop new technologies for investigating how the brain works. Using light and lasers, we can image cells within the living brain. However, to perform experiments that characterize and test properties of the brain, we also need to be able to cause changes in specific types of cells or processes and see what these changes do. The problem we sought to address here is that simply adding chemicals to the brain or body, or inserting electrodes into the brain causes major changes and damage that confound experiments. We recognized that there are many ways to leverage the properties of light itself to cause changes in the brain that would be more selective and less damaging – these included photouncaging, photocoagulation, optically-induced release of substances from microbubbles and optical tweezing. We proposed to develop a microscope platform that combined imaging with photomanipulation to enable novel experiments in rodent models to uncover how neural activity in the brain drives changes in blood flow (neurovascular coupling).

Intellectual Merit: Over the course of this project, our vision to combine optical imaging and optical manipulation has become a central approach in modern neuroscience, catalyzed by major growth in the use of optogenetics over the same period. In our work, we incorporated this idea of imaging while affecting change into many of our experiments, while also innovating on methods for implementing this combined approach. One major result was our use of a line of laser light to induce oxidative damage to endothelial cells lining blood vessels in the brain via excitation of an intravascular fluorophore. This important experiment allowed us to demonstrate that endothelial signaling is a critical component of neurovascular coupling. This has led to a wide range of new studies focusing on determining how endothelial dysfunction in common diseases such as diabetes could affect blood flow regulation in the brain. We have also combined photomanipulation with rapidly evolving genetically-encoded fluorescent calcium indicators, allowing us to optically induce a photothrombic acute stroke and observe how both neural activity and blood flow and oxygenation are affected in parallel. This work is providing new insights into the early progression of stroke, how it might appear on human brain imaging scans. Our results are the first step towards characterizing the entire acute-through-recovery trajectory in a single mouse in terms of both neural and hemodynamic representations in the brain, and changes in physical and cognitive abilities.

This project also stimulated major technical developments, including our development of a dual-beam two-photon microscope incorporating a spatial light modulator for both beam shaping and patterning and wavefront correction. In parallel, we developed a breakthrough new microscopy technology called swept confocally aligned planar excitation (SCAPE) microscopy, that enables very high speed volumetric imaging of cellular activity and is ideally suited to incorporation of optical manipulation techniques. Published in Nature Photonics in 2015, this technology is now being developed commercially under license with Leica Microsystems, giving SCAPE the potential to have worldwide impact. In our continuing development of SCAPE and its extension to two-photon under an NIH BRAIN initiative grant, our experience with spatial light modulation, pattern generation and wavefront correction is proving invaluable.

This project also supported development of a new area of research in the lab relating to micro-encapsulation of pharmacological agents for light-induced release. This work was performed in collaboration with Drs Claure Lunardi and Andersen Gomes from the University of Brasilia; chemistry faculty with significant experience in encapsulation and its combination with fluorescence. These visiting scientists spent over a year in our lab developing new approaches to encapsulation and release while also learning from us a range of state of the art in-vivo imaging strategies that have since positively impacted their own research back in Brazil.

Broader impacts: In addition to developing and demonstrating new technologies that we are making available to researchers worldwide, this project also catalyzed important new scientific discoveries related to brain physiology that we are continuing to build upon. A total of 14 undergraduate and 6 graduate students contributed to this research, gaining substantial experience in interdisciplinary neuroscience and imaging research. Our external outreach activities centered on establishing a design-based enrichment program where graduate students worked with local high schools to engage juniors and seniors in STEM subjects. With the closure of our collaborating school, we extended these efforts to outreach at local K-8 schools with hands-on experiments relating to biomedical imaging and optics. A new freshman-level biomedical design curriculum was also developed and implemented.

Overall, this NSF CAREER project provided critical support for the development of key technologies, and drove important new scientific discoveries in my lab. This support enabled me to establish my core research directions and outreach involvement during the early development and maturation of my lab. Thank you!
